content.description:
Another powerful compression line. This one might definitely be height dependent as you'll need every possible inch to span this boulder.  

  SDS squeezing the prow and work your way up the left and right arete until its possible to mantle over the top.
content.protection: 2-3 pads. This one was given the pg-13 safety rating only because of the possibility of swinging off this boulder and falling into a pit.
content.location: Slightly behind Riding the Elephant is a cluster of smaller boulders. This one is somewhat hard to find but look for a boulder protruding from a small pit.

content.description:
Like many of the classic lines at Haycock, this is all about compression.  

  SDS on obvious, yet low, jug. Dyno up to slopers on the faint lip and then trend leftwards. Climb up the prow and then trend back right slightly towards the topout finish.
content.protection: 2-3 pads. The start is a bit tight with an unfortunate boulder to your back.

content.description: Climb the overhanging arete in the pit. Make a huge throw to a slopey rail.
content.location: The James Brown Area...from Glass Wall, pass Red Wool, pass Riding the Elephant. Climb is in a pit and difficult to find. Good luck!

content.description: There is not a high concentration of climbs in this area, but it is in close proximity to some of the other more frequented areas. It can be easy to get lost in this area due to the heavy amount of jumbled talus and shrub growth. What the area lacks in concentration, it makes up in quality. Some excellent problems worth checking out in this section.
